text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Statistics released by Assistant Minister for Health Basil Criticos show that an average of 111 Kenyans die of AIDS daily.
- The High Court winds up the troubled Kenya National Assurance Company on the basis that it has failed to maintain solvency margins.

- Opposition member of parliament James Orengo, says powerful individuals are illegally importing a special type of paper used for printing banknotes in the name of a local company licensed to do the business, and using them to print fake notes.
- Electoral Commission Chairman Zaccheus Chesoni says that there is no time for Kenya to hold constitutional reforms before the next general election.

- Thirty-two Opposition members of parliament reject a government proposal to start an agricultural bank saying the most viable bank would be one sponsored by coffee, tea, dairy and horticultural farmers.
- The Democratic Party admits that it's activities are crippled because it has no money.

- After years of an unchallenged parliamentary career spanning some 40 years, President Moi is likely to face a challenger in his Baringo Central constituency in the forthcoming general election, from a candidate sponsored by an alliance of several clans of his Tugen sub-tribe of the Kalenjin ethnic group.
